I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 

1. 
partial credit guarantee (PCG) for the Janub Gas-Fired Power Plant Project.  
 
2. 
The  project  will  have  an  installed  capacity  of  780  megawatts  (MW)  and  will  cost  €691 
million.  It  will  replace  the  Shirvan  Thermal  Power  Plant  (TPP),  Azerbaijan's  second  largest 
power plant, which is more than 40 years old and now inefficient. The project will increase the 
stability  of  the  power  generation  system  in  Azerbaijan  and  improve  the  reliability  of  the  power 
supply  in  the  country's  industrial  and  economic  hub  in  the  Absheron  Peninsula.  By 
decommissioning the Shirvan TTP and replacing it with a plant with state-of-the-art technology, 
the  project  will  significantly  increase  power-generating  efficiency,  while  decreasing  the 
environmental  impact  of  power  generation  in  the  project  area.  The  PCG  will  support  a 
commercial  bank  loan  that  will  finance  maintenance  workshops,  heavy  fuel  tanks, a  treatment 
system, and laboratory equipment needed to complete the new plant and the decommissioning 
of the Shirvan TPP. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
Despite  the  global  economic  downturn,  Azerbaijan's  gross  domestic  product  increased 
by 10.8% in 2008, fueled by the export of new oil and gas production. Azerbaijan has abundant 
energy resources, with hydrocarbon reserves estimated at 7,000 billion barrels of oil equivalent.1 
However, efficiency and security in the power sector is a government priority, since excess fuel 
can  be  exported.2 Further,  the  poor  quality  and  reliability  of  the  electricity  supply  inhibits  the 
expansion of industrial, agriculture, and commercial activities, which are needed for Azerbaijan 
to  diversify  its  economy  away  from  hydrocarbon-related  sectors.  Low  power  plant  efficiency 
combined with transmission and distribution losses have wasted fossil fuels and nearly doubled 
greenhouse  gas  emissions  and  other  pollutants  that  damage  the  regional  and  global 
environment.  
 
The power sector has gone through a series of reforms. Sector restructuring has been 
4. 
achieved,  in  part  because  of  (i)  the  establishment  of  four  regional  distribution  companies;  (ii) 
private  sector  participation  in  generation;  and  (iii)  the  creation  of  the  Ministry  of  Economic 
Development, which is responsible for energy sector policy making, pricing and tariffs, licensing, 
and  management  of  fixed  assets.  The  Tariff  Council,  chaired  by  the  Ministry  of  Economic 
Development, has the authority to propose tariff adjustments, define customer categories, and 
adopt cost-reflective tariff design. All large companies had to change to International Financial 
Reporting  Standards  by  January  2008,  and  all  government  ministries  had  to  adopt  the 
International Public Reporting Standards by January 2009. The commercialization of Azerenerji 
Joint Stock Company (AzerEnergy), the state-owned enterprise responsible for management of 
major  thermal  and  hydropower  generation  plants,  transmission,  and  part  of  the  distribution 
network, has been accelerated. The aim is to turn AzerEnergy into a leading international power 
international  safeguard  standards. 
technology  and 
company  applying  state-of-the-art 
Azerbaijan's  development  partners  have  supported  the  creation  of  the  Investment  Department 
to tighten financial controls and the Ecology Unit to oversee safeguards. Both are progressing 
well.

More than 20% of all energy equipment and more than half of the network facilities have 
5. 
exceeded their useful life. Azerbaijan has been refurbishing and replacing old generation plants 
and  improving  transmission  and  distribution  infrastructure  to  increase  efficiency.  Although 
demand decreased in 2007 because of conservation measures that followed a rise in customer 
prices  to  a  cost  recovery  level,  a  4.0%  annual  increase  in  demand  is  forecast  to  2030.3 The 
current  shortfall  in  peak  load  is  about  300  MW.  However,  the  available  generation  capacity  is 
5,070  MW.  TPPs  generated  85%  of  the  power,  while  hydropower  plants  produce  15%.  Only 
32%  of  the  plants  are  running  at  optimal  capacity.  The  refurbishment  of  the  biggest  plants—
Azerbaijanskaya  and  Shirvan,  which  produce  57%  of  available  capacity—will  complete  the 
refurbishment plan.  
 
6. 
Starting  commercial  operations  in  1962,  the  Shirvan  TPP  is  the  second  biggest  power 
plant  in  Azerbaijan,  accounting  for  22%  of  electricity  production  in  2006–2007.  The  plant  has 
outlived  its  useful  life  as  demonstrated  by  a  thermal  efficiency  of  only  27%  and  available 
generation capacity of 600 MW (57% of its installed capacity). The plant has become unreliable 
and poses a threat to the power security of Azerbaijan.  
 
7. 
The project will be located within the same site as the Shirvan TPP to take advantage of 
the  existing  infrastructure,  such  as  overhead  lines,  gas  pipeline,  access  roads,  railways,  and 
stand-by fuel storage and handling facilities. In addition to ensuring energy security, the project 
will  (i)  have  an  average  efficiency  of  52%,4 (ii)  generate  efficiency  savings  by  reducing  costs 
from  €0.017  per  kilowatt  hour  (kWh)  to  €0.012 per  kWh,  (iii)  increase  exports  if  excess  gas  is 
exported  ($54.4  million  per  year),  and  (iv)  reduce  the  emissions  of  greenhouse  gas  and  other 
pollutants.  Given  the  considerable  benefits,  the  government  is  committed  to  fast-tracking  the 
project. 
 
8. 
The  original  financing  plan  called  for  government  funds  and  sovereign-guaranteed 
commercial bank loans to finance the entire cost of the project. In 2008, the first financing phase 
was successfully completed through a €284 million syndicated long-term commercial bank loan. 
However,  because  of  the  global  financial  crisis,  commercial  loans  became  scarce  and 
expensive in late 2008 when financing was sought for the second financing phase. The second 
round  of  financing  was  to  fund,  among  other  things,  the  maintenance  workshops,  heavy  fuel 
tanks, a treatment system, and the laboratory equipment needed to complete the new plant and 
the decommissioning of the Shirvan TPP.  
 
9. 
The PCG from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will support a commercial bank loan 
of up to €220 million to AzerEnergy. The PCG will double the maturity available and more than 
halve  the  interest  margin  that  would  be  charged  by  commercial  banks,  thereby  increasing  the 
financial and economic viability of the project. It will also mark the return of AzerEnergy to the 
international commercial bank debt market. 
 
In  the  latest  country  strategy  and  program  update  (2006),5 the  government  requested 
10. 
ADB  support  for  energy  within  an  expanded  lending  program,  particularly  for  power 
transmission and distribution, climate change mitigation, and improving AzerEnergy's access to 
capital markets. The Power Transmission Enhancement Project,6 approved in August 2008, is in 
line with this strategy.

 B. 

Impact and Outcome 

11. 
The  impact  will  be  an  improved  power  system  that  provides  electricity  needed  for 
sustained  economic  growth.  The  project  is  an  integral  part  of  Azerbaijan’s  power  sector 
development strategy. The outcome will be Azerenergy's increased capacity to provide efficient 
and reliable power to customers. ADB's assistance through the PCG will also (i) support reforms 
underway  to  strengthen  the  financial  position  and  transparency  of  AzerEnergy,  enabling  it  to 
operate  sustainably  and  independently;  (ii)  help  AzerEnergy  successfully  return  to  the 
international  commercial  bank  debt  market,7 and  diversify  and  deepen  Azerenergy's  funding 
sources; and (iii) set the stage for AzerEnergy's access to the international capital market in the 
medium term. 
 
The project will meet European emission standards. After the commissioning of the new 
12. 
plant,  the  Shirvan  TPP  will  be  decommissioned.  By  also  financing  the  Shirvan  TPP 
decommissioning from proceeds of the commercial loan, ADB will ensure that it is carried out in 
a  timely  manner  and  complies  with  ADB's  safeguard  policies  with  regard  to  precautionary 
measures.

A. 

Economic and Financial 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

An  economic  analysis  of  the  project  was  carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB 
23. 
guidelines. 14  The  project  has  an  estimated  base  case  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of 
17.35%.  The  project  will  (i)  increase  the  capacity  of  the  network  and  provide  enhanced 
electricity export opportunities to neighboring countries; (ii) reduce power generation from older 
and less-efficient facilities, and/or delay the construction of other new power generation plants; 
(iii)  improve  energy  efficiency,  which  will  result  in  projected  gas  savings  of  324  million  cubic 
meters  of  gas  per  year,  realizing  additional  export  revenues  of  €54.4  million  per  year;  (iv) 
produce  net  savings  in  non-gas  annual  operating  costs;  and  (v)  improve  power  generation 
reliability for consumers. 
 
A financial analysis of the project was carried out in accordance with ADB guidelines.15 
24. 
All  financial  costs  and  benefits  have  been  expressed  at  2009  prices.  Cost  streams  used  to 
determine  the  financial  internal  rate  of  return  (i.e.,  capital  investment,  and  operation  and 
maintenance) reflect the cost of delivering the estimated benefits. The tariff for electricity—the 
wholesale  rate  at  which  AzerEnergy  sells  electricity  to  the  distribution  companies—is  set  at 
€0.035 per 1 kWh, including the value-added tax. It is assumed that sufficient demand exists to 
allow the power station to operate at full capacity. The pricing of gas as the main energy source 
is  €0.04017  per  1,000  cubic  meters,  including  the  value-added  tax.  This  price  is  based  on  an 
annual  contract  at  the  state  determined  price.  The  financial  internal  rate  of  return  of  12.0% 
compares  favorably  with  the  estimated  weighted  average  cost  of  capital  of  2.4%,  indicating 
financial  viability  for  the  project.  Nonquantifiable  financial  benefits,  such  as  reliability  of  power 
supply, were not included in the financial analysis. 
 
B. 

Governance 

25. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with AzerEnergy and the government. This will also be done with the commercial banks when 
the PCG is negotiated. ADB will reserve the right to investigate, directly or through its agents, 
any alleged corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to the project. Relevant 
provisions of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy as well as its Policy on Combating Money Laundering 
and Financing of Terrorism (2003) will be included in the PCG and the commercial loan facility 
agreement. In particular, all contracts financed by the commercial loan shall include provisions 
specifying  the  right  of  ADB  to  audit  and  examine  the  records  and  accounts  of  all  contractors, 
suppliers, consultants, agents, and others as they relate to the project.  
 
C. 

Poverty and Social 

26. 
By increasing the supply of efficient and reliable electricity to the system, the project will 
ensure the stable supply of power to people in the rural and urban areas for their commercial 
and social activities. The lack of sufficient electricity, along with gas and heat, has aggravated

 the  regional  imbalances  in  the  country.  Poor-quality  and  unreliable  electricity  supply  inhibits 
industrial,  agricultural,  and  commercial  activities,  constraining  economic  growth  and 
employment opportunities in regional areas. 
 
D. 

Safeguards 

Operation.  Monitoring  and  reporting  during  operation  will  follow  the  provisions  in  the 

27. 
Construction.  During  construction,  the  project  will  not  have  any  major  environmental 
impacts.  Project  implementation  will  require  environmental  monitoring  and  reporting  during 
construction,  as  detailed  in  the  environmental  management  and  monitoring  plan  (EMMP),  to 
avoid  standard  construction  impacts.  This  will  also  ensure  that  mitigating  procedures  are 
implemented.  These  measures  include  controlling  runoff  via  sedimentation  ponds,  building 
bunds  around  fuel  and  oil  storage  areas,  cleaning  up  construction  sites,  properly  disposing  of 
spoils,  grading  damaged  land  and  replanting  vegetation,  and  protecting  the  public  from 
excessive noise and dust during construction. Special handling will be required with respect to 
toxic  polychlorinated  biphenyls  in  transformer  cooling  oil,  if  any.  AzerEnergy  has  assured  that 
the new transformers will be filled with a nontoxic substitute for polychlorinated biphenyls. Since 
the  Ecology  Unit  of  AzerEnergy  does  not  have  sufficient  skills  to  implement  an  EMMP 
effectively,  ADB  is  funding  an  international  specialist  to  provide  training  in  environmental 
management. 
 
Decommissioning  and  demolition.  Environmental  safeguards  dealing  with  the 
28. 
decommissioning  and  demolition  of  the  old  Shirvan  TPP  will  need  to  be  clearly  defined  in  the 
decommissioning and demolition contract. These safeguards will apply to the 12 old 5,000 cubic 
meter  oil  tanks  and  possibly  also  to  the  6  newer  20,000  cubic  meter  oil  tanks  along  with  the 
loading  and  handling  facilities.  They  will  need  to  take  into  consideration  relevant  Azeri 
environmental laws and regulations, as well as international standards. 
 
29. 
EMMP added to the current contract for the project. 
 
30. 
Resettlement  and  employment.  A  total  of  60  families  (pensioners  and  current  TPP 
employees),  including  three  refugee  families  were  living  in  the  employee  apartments  in  the 
location  where  the  project  is  being  built.  A  new  five-story  apartment  block  was  built  in  the 
nearest  town  of  Shirvan  and  the  families  have  been  resettled  there  with  AzerEnergy's 
assistance.  A  due  diligence  activity  of  the  relocation  process  of  Janub  TPP  employees  was 
conducted  and  concluded  that  the  relocation  activities  carried  out  are  consistent  with  the 
requirements of the ADB's Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995). The main results of the due 
diligence  are:  (i)  there  is  no  loss  of  income  experienced  by  the  affected  families  due  to  the 
relocation  activity;  (ii)  the  project  had  provided  the  affected  families  with  new  apartments  in  a 
better  condition  with  the  required  facilities  and  infrastructure;  (iii)  the  affected  gardens  in  the 
previous location cannot be replaced in the new location, but there was no complaint from the 
affected  families  and  the  activity  was  no  longer  essential  since  produce  and  other  vegetables 
can  now  be  acquired  from  the  nearby  market;  (iv)  all  the  associated  costs  related  to  the 
relocation/resettlement activities were fully covered by the project; and (v) the affected families 
were fully informed on the project activities through a series of consultation meetings and gave 
their  full  agreement  to  the  project.  Based  on  the  above,  the  project  is  classified  as  “C”  for 
involuntary  resettlement.  However,  resettlement  plans  in  accordance  with  the  Safeguard 
Requirements 2 of the Safeguard Policy Statement will be prepared if unanticipated involuntary 
resettlement impacts should occur.16

Employment. In 2007, when the Shirvan TPP was in full operation with six of the seven 
32. 
turbines running, it employed 1,012 people. The number of employees needed to run the plant 
decreased, as new and more efficient plants have come on line. The Shirvan TPP staff dropped 
from  964  in  2008  to  381  in  late  2009.  Since  2007,  more  than  170  have  retired  and  460  were 
reemployed with the assistance of AzerEnergy at various industrial and construction companies. 
In addition to receiving a pension or severance payment, many of the former employees have 
small  businesses  and  small  plots  of  land  for  farming  in  Shirvan  district.  About  100  employees 
will  be  needed  to  operate  the  project  plant.  Of  these,  40  will  come  from  the  old  Shirvan  TPP. 
This  will  result  in  341  additional  redundancies,  and  they  will  be  assisted  in  reemployment, 
offered  retirement,  retrained  for  work  inside  AzerEnergy,  or  given  severance  payment  in 
accordance with national laws.
